===Online activism and the role of social media===
===Online activism and the role of social media===
  +
{{ref improve section}}
[[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a Facebook group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.<ref>{{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date=8 February 2011|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work=CBC News|accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> Later after the revolution, in an TV interview in the presence of member of the ruling military council, it was revealed that AbdulRahman Mansour, a young underground activist and media expert shared the account with Wael Ghonim.<ref>{{cite news|title = ØªÙØ±ÙØ± Ø®Ø§Øµ- ÙÙ Ø¯Ø§Ø®Ù Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ©|url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE73C0QW20110413?sp=true|date=13 April 2011|agency=Reuters |format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.<ref>{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date=4 February 2011|work=National Public Radio|format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.'<ref>{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date=18 February 2011|publisher=[[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|work=The Nation|accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref>
[[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a Facebook group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.<ref>{{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date=8 February 2011|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work=CBC News|accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> Later after the revolution, in an TV interview in the presence of member of the ruling military council, it was revealed that AbdulRahman Mansour, a young underground activist and media expert shared the account with Wael Ghonim.<ref>{{cite news|title = ØªÙØ±ÙØ± Ø®Ø§Øµ- ÙÙ Ø¯Ø§Ø®Ù Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ©|url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE73C0QW20110413?sp=true|date=13 April 2011|agency=Reuters |format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.<ref>{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date=4 February 2011|work=National Public Radio|format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.'<ref>{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date=18 February 2011|publisher=[[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|work=The Nation|accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 706: Line 707:
The role of social media in the Egyptian uprising has since been widely written and debated about, including in the first edition of the [[Dubai Debates]] on the question "Mark Zuckerberg â the new hero of the Arab people?"
The role of social media in the Egyptian uprising has since been widely written and debated about, including in the first edition of the [[Dubai Debates]] on the question "Mark Zuckerberg â the new hero of the Arab people?"
<ref>[http://www.dubaidebates.com/debates/view/1/mark-zuckerberg-the-new-hero-of-the-arab-people]</ref>
<ref>[http://www.dubaidebates.com/debates/view/1/mark-zuckerberg-the-new-hero-of-the-arab-people]</ref>
  +   +
==Ongoing Revolution==
  +
{{ref improve section}}
  +
Beginning July 8th revolutionaries in Tahrir square have begun another sit-in which stands to this day. Initially because of the fact that the army would not fire on the citizens in the first uprising that started in January, slogans were chanted that the people and the Army are one. However, now that Egypt is under rule of the Army and there has been no good progress for true liberty and equality for Egyptians, the Egyptian revolutionary people have decided that the Army ruler has lost his legitimacy. One protester pointed out that the people gave legitimacy to the Army when they decided to leave Tahrir square. But since the Army also seems to be corrupt and is not following the people's demands there is now another ongoing protest and sit-in in Tahrir square that promises to practice escalating civil disobedience. This is now the "Law of Protest" in Egypt which is the true ruling party of Egypt, not the so-called military.
==See also==
==See also==

Ongoing Revolution
  â
Beginning July 8th revolutionaries in Tahrir square have begun another sit-in which stands to this day. Initially because of the fact that the army would not fire on the citizens in the first uprising that started in January, slogans were chanted that the people and the Army are one. However, now that Egypt is under rule of the Army and there has been no good progress for true liberty and equality for Egyptians, the Egyptian revolutionary people have decided that the Army ruler has lost his legitimacy. One protester pointed out that the people gave legitimacy to the Army when they decided to leave Tahrir square. But since the Army also seems to be corrupt and is not following the people's demands there is now another ongoing protest and sit-in in Tahrir square that promises to practice escalating civil disobedience. This is now the "Law of Protest" in Egypt which is the true ruling party of Egypt, not the so-called military.
